title: How should I write a wedding ceremony for a novel? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can either use an existing ceremony or borrow from other cultures. If you do borrow from other cultures, the “safest” route, if you want to avoid the shrill harpies screeching “cultural appropriation!!1111!!!” it’s safest to borrow from something “dead,” like ancient Etruscan or Egyptian ceremonies.

Attend a few weddings, make notes. Watch some YouTube weddings, make notes. Locate information about weddings that fit your time period, culture and theme. If modern day, talk to officiants and newly wedded couples. How did they feel during the ceremony? What moments was memorable, tender, emotional? Now write and do the re-write thing a few times and soon you’ll have an awesome wedding ceremony and a terrific best seller. Please forward a copy of the ceremony or your novels title, so I too, may enjoy . . . Thanks

Thanks for the A2A The best description comes from a wedding that you personally attended. The scenes turn out real, the feeling of a wedding is authentic, and the reader tends to be in on the scene. Anything else feels contrived. Of course, you can watch a movie and try describing that but it feels like second-hand and unreal. Good luck. Get yourself invited t a real wedding or just get married and describe it all firsthand. Haha Thanks for asking.

There’s a good example of a wedding party at the beginning of Upton Sinclair’s “The Jungle”. Zola’s “L’Assomoir” has an even better one. Read and analyze these and think about what makes them so good, then go and do likewise—hopefully, after having attended at least one such ceremony yourself.
